content: The "Collegiate Learning and Student Savings Act" allows eligible educational institutions to maintain qualified tuition programs. The "Collegiate Learning and Student Savings Act" allows eligible educational institutions to maintain qualified tuition programs, including those established by a consortium of institutions. Private qualified tuition programs are limited to benefit plans, with certain conforming amendments made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Collegiate Learning and Student Savings Act" amends section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code by replacing "qualified State tuition" with "qualified tuition". The "Collegiate Learning and Student Savings Act" amends section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code to replace "qualified State tuition" with "qualified tuition". The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow distributions for qualified higher education expenses without including them in gross income. The Internal Revenue Code allows distributions for qualified higher education expenses to be excluded from gross income. In-kind distributions to designated beneficiaries under a qualified State tuition program are treated as distributions for tax purposes. The Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of qualified higher education expenses from gross income. No deduction or credit is allowed for these expenses if already excluded. Beneficiaries can change programs under Section 529(c)(3)(C) by transferring to another qualified tuition program. The Internal Revenue Code allows exclusion of qualified higher education expenses from gross income. Beneficiaries can change programs under Section 529(c)(3)(C) by transferring to another qualified tuition program. In the heading, "or programs" is inserted after "beneficiaries." Additional tax on amounts not used for higher education expenses is imposed on payments and distributions from qualified tuition programs in the same manner as it applies to education individual retirement accounts. Coordination with education credits is amended to include "a qualified tuition program or" before "an education individual retirement account." The amendments made by this section apply to distributions for education after specific dates, depending on the type of program. For qualified tuition programs not run by a State, the changes apply to distributions after December 31, 2003. SEC. 4 amends the Securities Act of 1933 to include securities issued by prepaid tuition programs under the exemption. It also specifies that prepaid tuition programs described in section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code are not considered investment companies under the Investment Company Act of 1940.
